text: is a prefecture in the Kyūshū region of Japan on the island of Kyushu.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2002)."Kumamoto prefecture" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 572; Japan External Trade Organization (JETRO), Kumamoto Prefecture, Regional Information. Retrieved 2012-4-6. The capital city is Kumamoto.Nussbaum, "Kumamoto" at p. 572. == History == The area of Higo Province was renamed Kumamoto during the Meiji Restoration.Nussbaum, "Provinces and prefectures" at p. 780. ===Timeline=== * 1607-1614 (Keichō 12-19): Kumamoto Castle, construction lasted 7 yearsTrends in Japan, "Kumamoto, Famed for Its Castle and Caldera". Retrieved 2012-2-7. * December 1637 (Kan'ei 14): Shimabara RebellionNussbaum, "Shimabara no Ran" at pp. 857-858; Visit Kumamoto, Kumamoto history. Retrieved 2012-2-7. * May 21, 1792 (Kansei 4, 1st day of the 4th month): Earthquake centered at Mount Unzen caused tsunami which hit HigoNational Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Geophysical Data Center, Significant Earthquake. Retrieved 2012-2-7 == Geography == Kumamoto Prefecture is in the middle of Kyūshū The western border of Kumamoto is the Ariake Sea and the Amakusa Islands. Fukuoka Prefecture and Ōita Prefecture are in the north. Miyazaki Prefecture is in the east. Kagoshima Prefecture is in the south. Mount Aso (1592 m) is an active volcano in the eastern part of the prefecture.Nussbaum, "Aso-san" at p. 58. ===Cities=== *Amakusa *Arao *Aso *Hitoyoshi *Kami-Amakusa *Kikuchi *Kōshi :*Kumamoto (capital) :*Minamata :*Tamana :*Uki :*Uto :*Yamaga :*Yatsushiro ===National Parks=== National Parks are established in about 21% of the total land area of the prefecture,Japan Ministry of the Environment, "General overview of area figures for Natural Parks by prefecture". Retrieved 2012-3-13. including * Aso Kujū National Park ==Shrines and Temples== Aso- jinja is the chief Shinto shrines (ichinomiya) in the prefecture. "Nationwide List of Ichinomiya," p. 3 .
